steps.title: Change your sewing machine needle.
steps.content: Change your sewing machine needle. Your regular needle might be okay for sewing organza, but it is best to check it first. You will need a size 8 to 11 (60 to 75) universal needle for working with organza fabric. [1] X Research source You could also try using a small size sharp point needle. These are usually best for sewing with delicate fabrics. Make sure you have changed your needle recently. You should replace your needle after every project or at least after every four hours of sewing with the same needle. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Sew with a regular weight cotton thread.
steps.content: Sew with a regular weight cotton thread. You don’t need to get a specialty thread to work with organza. Just use a regular weight cotton thread to sew your project. [3] X Research source Opt for a color that is close to the color of your fabric to help the stitches blend in. Otherwise, they may stand out and this may look unappealing. For example, if you are using a pale pink organza fabric, then opt for a pale pink thread to match.

steps.title: Set your machine to the straight stitch setting.
steps.content: Set your machine to the straight stitch setting. When sewing with organza, your best bet is to use the straight stitch setting. This is the most basic stitch you can use and it will result in a straight, clean line. Avoid using fancy stitches for organza fabric. [4] X Research source After you have your straight stitch seam, you may want to add a zigzag seam next to it towards the outer edge. This can help to reinforce the seam and the seam won’t be visible because it will be on the outer edge. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Avoid backstitching.
steps.content: Avoid backstitching. It is important to avoid backstitching with organza fabric because this can damage the fabric. Only sew across your fabric one time and in one direction. Make sure that all of your settings are correct before you begin. [6] X Research source Also, keep in mind that you cannot use a seam ripper for organza fabrics. Tearing out stitches will damage the fabric. If you make a mistake, then you might need to just get new fabric and start over.

steps.title: Hold the fabric on both sides.
steps.content: Hold the fabric on both sides. To avoid puckering, it is important to place even pressure on both sides of the organza as you sew. Keep one hand behind the presser foot and the other hand in front of it to hold the organza. Keep the fabric taut, but don’t stretch it or apply too much pressure or it may tear or affect the stitching. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Run tests on a piece of scrap fabric first.
steps.content: Run tests on a piece of scrap fabric first. Before you start sewing your organza, try testing your stitches on a scrap piece of organza fabric first. This will help to ensure that the stitch you are using will not damage your fabric and give you a chance to adjust your settings before you work on the actual project. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Opt for simple designs.
steps.content: Opt for simple designs. Sheers like organza are fancy enough on their own, so it is not necessary to use an intricate design when you are working with them. Instead, opt for simple designs that will showcase the fabric. [9] X Research source For example, you might want to avoid things like pleating and intricate draping.

steps.title: Pre-wash your fabric
steps.content: Pre-wash your fabric only if necessary. If you anticipate needing to wash it later on, then it is important to do a pre-wash before sewing to ensure that the fabric will not shrink after you sew it. [10] X Research source Keep in mind that it is generally best not to wash organza, so if you do not anticipate needing to wash it, then don’t pre-wash it. [11] X Research source Also, be aware that pre-washing organza will soften the fabric, so it may not provide the same amount of structure before it has been washed. [12] X Research source

steps.title: Press the fabric with a dry iron if needed.
steps.content: Press the fabric with a dry iron if needed. If your fabric is wrinkled or creased, then you may want to press it before you sew. However, the steam from an iron can leave water spots or cause discoloration to organza fabric. Use a dry iron to press the fabric if needed. [13] X Research source Make sure that the iron is on the lowest setting. [14] X Research source

steps.title: Hold down the edges when measuring and cutting.
steps.content: Hold down the edges when measuring and cutting. Organza is slippery, so it is important to weigh it down to prevent it from moving while you measure and cut it. You can use weights, push pins, or tape to hold down your fabric. [15] X Research source Try using double sided tape to attach the organza to your work surface. [16] X Research source Keep in mind that pinning can damage the fabric, so use them sparingly, if at all. [17] X Research source

steps.title: Use a pencil, pen, or chalk to mark the fabric.
steps.content: Use a pencil, pen, or chalk to mark the fabric. Organza can get stained easily, so avoid using a marker or anything else that might not come off the fabric easily. A pencil, pen, or piece of chalk will probably work best for marking. [18] X Research source Test out your marking method on a scrap piece of fabric first to see if it will come out easily.
